text: Welcome Friends families and loved ones
and thank you for all of your support in
helping the HBS class of
2016 reach this moment I'm Ana Hayden
and I'm Brad minko it has been a
privilege to serve as your student
Association co-presidents over the last
year and we are thrilled to speak before
you here today and to show our gratitude
we promise to keep our remarks brief
because as they say it's best to leave
your audience before your audience
leaves you absolutely so let's jump in
with what it is we've exactly been up to
here for the past two years and it
hasn't just been hanging out with Will
Wiston of section
g or the unbeatable section e

this concludes our Charity Auction
shoutouts no since day one at HBS we
have been asked to very big questions
what do you plan to do with your one
wild and precious life and how will you
be a leader who makes a difference in
the world one or two of us are still
working on our answers but continue to
work on we will because it is no small
thing to be here today I spent January
of my first year working with a company
in Vietnam through our field program
after getting to know each other a bit
our local guide told us what you should
know about my culture is that we believe
in three kinds of karma he paused after
the first two and then said the Third
Kind of karma is that if you are very
good in this life you will come back in
the next life as something very special
I hope to come back in my next life as a
Harvard Business School
student we're so lucky to be here we're
so lucky to have this school this
community as part of our lives and as my
mother would say to whom much is given
much is
expected as Anya alluded to we have a
program here called the portrait project
and graduating students answer one
question oh what is it you will do with
your one wild and precious
life a handful of these responses are
then shared with incoming students on
the very first day of their first year
and I remember going through this
exercise
myself there was one portrait in
particular that stood out and it read we
have a duty to not let graduating from
Harvard be the greatest accomplishment
of our
lives but if I ask myself as I stand
here today is graduating from HBS the
greatest accomplishment of my life to
date I would have to say yes and that's
not because HBS is the end no it's
because this is just the beginning of a
journey to do remarkable things in a
world that truly needs help and our
graduation is the boarding pass to
finally get started for no matter who we
were or where we came from prior to
matriculating we leave here tomorrow
with this incredible platform and
Mission to actually influence the
world not many people have that
privilege
but we do and so it's not a matter of if
we will make a difference in the world
it's a matter of how and the how well
that's really up to you our graduates
but we ask that you please do
something we did not come to Harvard to
be ordinary we came here to be
extraordinary and the most extraordinary
thing we can do is to serve a mission
greater than ourselves and in doing so
that's how we can look back one day and
say no graduating from HBS was not the
greatest accomplishment of Our Lives we
want to emphasize that point there is no
one right path to accomplishment there's
just your path to what you believe
matters there is no race to a Finish
Line there's just your journey as part
of our final HBS send off we were gifted
with pages and pages of advice from
alums reading on the same Spangler lawn
they knew so well I reach page 14 male
class of 2002 married or domestic
partner has children New York New York
The Prompt reads how would you reflect
on your experience what changes would
you make if you
could I assume that like any good HBS
case protagonist he first stares
pensively out the window and then
answers I would not mind taking a slower
path to success many HBS grads aim for
achievement and progress partner or CEO
fund launch billion dooll exit as
quickly as possible but happiness
doesn't come from achieving goals as
quickly as possible he describes Clint
Eastwood who achieved his biggest Awards
and box off its hits in his 70s and 80s
versus young stars who quickly faded
away he continues many people know that
they should make decisions for the long
term
but very few people actually do I
realize more and more that having a 25
or even 50-year time Horizon would have
changed my decision- making for the
better regarding what to learn what type
of work to prioritize and how to
allocate time to Family Health work in
the day-to-day context
so what would you do differently what
decisions would you make differently if
you were living like life for quality
over speed if you weren't gunning for
your destination as quickly as possible
but instead every day we're pulling
ahead as best spouse or parent co-worker
or boss volunteer or friend because if
we are actually living for quality over
Speed The Journey itself promps us to be
at least as sweet as the destination
ever could be exactly and we are well on
our way graduates the road ahead may be
long the obstacles unknown which can be
especially scary for a bunch of typ a
individuals who love to plan but we are
on our way and how can we know this well
for the past two years Anna and I have
had the good privilege to get to know so
many of you we have heard how lucky you
feel to be here and that you understand
the responsibilities that come with this
we have seen your extraordinary talents
and so so we are confident that you will
achieve things greater than graduating
from Harvard and we have experienced the
way you live life toward quality not
speed but perhaps you're still
unconvinced and that's okay because
we're about to show you so to our fellow
students we ask that you please indulge
us one final time and rise and remain
standing emphasis on the remain standing
if the following relates to you and and
to our families though we know you love
us please hold your applause until the
very
end
okay so please rise and remain
standing if you served as a leader for
your section a club or the Student
Association if you are graduating with
first or second year honors
if you have donated your time money or
energy to your
passion if you've helped a friend in or
out of the
classroom if you've made the tough
choice the right choice even when it was
not the most convenient
one lastly if you've pushed yourself for
something that really mattered to you
even when no one was watching please
rise this is how we
know this is how we know this class will
achieve many great things along a
journey that promises to be just as rich
and this this is the group that will be
there by your side every step of the way
this is friendship for a lifetime this
is leadership for the future this is the
Harvard Business School class of 2016
